**Background and Early Life**

50 Cent, born Curtis James Jackson III, was born on November 6, 1975, in the South Jamaica neighborhood of Queens, New York City. He is of Trinidadian and African American descent. As a child, he experienced significant adversity, with his mother serving multiple prison terms for robbery, and his father being incarcerated for drug-related offenses. These challenging circumstances led him into the life of crime during his teenage years.

**Entry into the Music Industry**

50 Cent made his first breakthrough in the music industry in 2002 with his debut album "Get Rich or Die Tryin'," which became a commercial and critical success. The album's lead single, "In Da Club," became a hit, and its music video received millions of views on MTV. The album featured collaborations with high-profile artists such as Eminem, Dr. Dre, and Obie Trice.

**Success and Business Ventures**

Following the success of "Get Rich or Die Tryin'," 50 Cent continued to make a name for himself in the hip-hop world. He released several critically acclaimed and commercially successful albums, including "The Massacre" in 2005 and "Before I Self Destruct" in 2009. Along with his musical career, he ventured into entrepreneurship, founding his clothing line, G-Unit Apparel, and his record label, G-Unit Records.

50 Cent also founded G-Unit Records in 2003, a record label that produced multiple successful artists, such as Lloyd Banks, Young Buck, and Tony Yayo. Additionally, he founded G-Unit South in 2007, which focuses on the development of up-and-coming talent in the southern music scene.

**Personal Life**

50 Cent has been married four times, and he has six children with three different women. His personal life has been marked by several high-profile legal issues, including arrests for assault and marijuana possession.

Throughout his career, 50 Cent has been known for his hard-hitting lyrics, storytelling ability, and unapologetic approach to his life and career.

50 Cent's influence extended beyond the music industry when he became the CEO of his record label, G-Unit Records, in 2003.
